revision.comment: Created page with "Addition and subtraction of infinite decimals includes some easy problems and some hard problems. Even for finite decimals, identities without carrying are easy to verify ({{m..."
revision.text:
Addition and subtraction of infinite decimals includes some easy problems and some hard problems. Even for finite decimals, identities without carrying are easy to verify ({{math|1=123456 + 654321 = 777777}}), whereas calculations with long runs of carrying are relatively hard to perform ({{math|1=3456 + 6549 = ???}}). A similar phenomenon occurs for infinite decimals.
Fortunately, we will not be encountering any addition problems with carrying, so we can concentrate on a few simple proofs of identities without carrying.
==Assumptions== *[[0.999.../Definition from series|Definition from series]] *[[0.999.../Term-by-term operations on series|Term-by-term operations on series]]
==Theorems==
===Addition by digits is correct=== ;Statement If there are three decimals {{math|1=''A'' = ''a''<sub>0</sub>.''a''<sub>1</sub>''a''<sub>2</sub>''a''<sub>3</sub>…}}, {{math|1=''B'' = ''b''<sub>0</sub>.''b''<sub>1</sub>''b''<sub>2</sub>''b''<sub>3</sub>…}}, and {{math|1=''C'' = ''c''<sub>0</sub>.''c''<sub>1</sub>''c''<sub>2</sub>''c''<sub>3</sub>…}} such that for every index {{math|''n''}}, {{math|1=''a''<sub>''n''</sub> + ''b''<sub>''n''</sub> = ''c''<sub>''n''</sub>}}, then {{math|1=''A'' + ''B'' = ''C''}}.
;Proof We apply the [[0.999.../Definition from series|definition of an infinite decimal as a series]]:
:<math> C = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{c_n}{10^n} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{a_n + b_n}{10^n}. </math>
Next we apply the fact that [[0.999.../Term-by-term operations on series|sums of series can be computed term-by-term]]:
:<math> C = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{a_n}{10^n} + \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{b_n}{10^n} = A + B. </math>
===Subtraction by digits is correct=== ;Statement If there are three decimals {{math|1=''A'' = ''a''<sub>0</sub>.''a''<sub>1</sub>''a''<sub>2</sub>''a''<sub>3</sub>…}}, {{math|1=''B'' = ''b''<sub>0</sub>.''b''<sub>1</sub>''b''<sub>2</sub>''b''<sub>3</sub>…}}, and {{math|1=''C'' = ''c''<sub>0</sub>.''c''<sub>1</sub>''c''<sub>2</sub>''c''<sub>3</sub>…}} such that for every index {{math|''n''}}, {{math|1=''a''<sub>''n''</sub> − ''b''<sub>''n''</sub> = ''c''<sub>''n''</sub>}}, then {{math|1=''A'' − ''B'' = ''C''}}.
;Proof The proof is almost identical to the previous proof:
:<math> C = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{c_n}{10^n} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{a_n - b_n}{10^n} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{a_n}{10^n} - \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{b_n}{10^n} = A + B. </math>
==The road not taken== If {{math|''A''}} and {{math|''B''}} are arbitrary infinite decimals, then it can be tricky to compute the decimal expansion of {{math|1=''A'' + ''B'' = ''C''}}. The problem is caused by the phenomenon of carrying from one digit to the next. To compute any given digit of {{math|''C''}}, one might need to inspect many more digits of {{math|''A''}} and {{math|''B''}} to make sure that their sum doesn't carry into the target digit.
This book does not explore the addition of arbitrary decimals, mostly because it is difficult and unnecessary.
[[Category:0.999...|{{SUBPAGENAME}}]]
{{Allbooks category}}
{{Allbooks category}}

revision.comment: Created page with "Multiplication of infinite decimals is usually challenging because it involves a great deal of carrying. Fortunately, as in the cases of [[0.999.../Decimal addition and subtra..."
revision.text:
Multiplication of infinite decimals is usually challenging because it involves a great deal of carrying. Fortunately, as in the cases of [[0.999.../Decimal addition and subtraction|addition and subtraction]], we are interested in identities that involve no carrying at all.
==Assumptions== *[[0.999.../Definition from series|Definition from series]] *[[0.999.../Term-by-term operations on series|Term-by-term operations on series]]
==Theorem== ;Statement If there are two decimals {{math|1=''A'' = ''a''<sub>0</sub>.''a''<sub>1</sub>''a''<sub>2</sub>''a''<sub>3</sub>…}} and {{math|1=''B'' = ''b''<sub>0</sub>.''b''<sub>1</sub>''b''<sub>2</sub>''b''<sub>3</sub>…}} and an integer {{math|''m''}} such that for every index {{math|''n''}}, {{math|1=''m'' × ''a''<sub>''n''</sub> = ''b''<sub>''n''</sub>}}, then {{math|1=''m'' × ''A'' = ''B''}}.
;Proof We apply the [[0.999.../Definition from series|definition of an infinite decimal as a series]]:
:<math> B = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{b_n}{10^n} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty m \frac{a_n}{10^n}. </math>
Next we apply the fact that [[0.999.../Term-by-term operations on series|a scalar multiple of a series can be computed term-by-term]]:
:<math> B = m \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{a_n}{10^n} = mA. </math>
[[Category:0.999...|{{SUBPAGENAME}}]]
{{Allbooks category}}
{{Allbooks category}}
{{Allbooks category}}
{{Allbooks category}}
{{Allbooks category}}

revision.comment: Created page with "Multiplying an infinite decimal by 10 is just as simple as multiplying an finite decimal by 10: every digit shifts one space to the left. ==Assumptions== *[[0.999.../Definiti..."
revision.text:
Multiplying an infinite decimal by 10 is just as simple as multiplying an finite decimal by 10: every digit shifts one space to the left.
==Assumptions== *[[0.999.../Definition from series|Definition from series]] *[[0.999.../Term-by-term operations on series|Term-by-term operations on series]] *[[0.999.../Shifting a series|Shifting a series]]
==Theorem== ;Statement If {{math|1=''A'' = 0.''a''<sub>1</sub>''a''<sub>2</sub>''a''<sub>3</sub>…}} then {{math|1=10 × ''A'' = ''a''<sub>1</sub>.''a''<sub>2</sub>''a''<sub>3</sub>''a''<sub>4</sub>…}}
;Proof We apply the [[0.999.../Definition from series|definition of an infinite decimal as a series]]:
:<math> A = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{a_n}{10^n}. </math>
Next we apply the fact that [[0.999.../Term-by-term operations on series|a scalar multiple of a series can be computed term-by-term]]:
:<math> 10A = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{10a_n}{10^n} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{a_n}{10^{n-1}}. </math>
Next we [[0.999.../Shifting a series|Shifting a series|shift the series]]:
:<math> 10A = a_0 + \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{a_{n+1}}{10^{(n+1)-1}}. </math>
But {{math|1=''a''<sub>0</sub> = 0}} by assumption, so we can simplify:
:<math> 10A = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{a_{n+1}}{10^n}, </math>
which is the desired result.
[[Category:0.999...|{{SUBPAGENAME}}]]

==Introduction== [[File:Membrane Curvature.png|thumb|membrane curvature]] :Curved membranes recruit large densities of alkylated proteins independent of affinity, with no requirement for specific recognition motifs. The biological curved membrane is identified the lipid composition and the action of membrane-bending proteins.
==Function== :The membrane curvature can regulate the localization of proteins with specific recognition motifs. Amphipathic alpha helices are critical membrane curvature sensors with a large range of proteins included with larger affinity for positively curved membranes through the recognition of curve defects in lipid packing. The membrane curvature dependent measurements, mostly made in vitro, are averaged across liposomes of variant diameter. These measurements reduce the accuracy and make calculation of affinity more difficult.
==Hypothesis== :Scientist Dimitrios Stamou and his fellows eliminated the problem of the calculations by using the fluorescence microscopy to determine membrane curvature- selective binding on individual liposomes. Their studies reveal the curved membranes can accommodate at a high density of amphiphilic molecules. Therefore, the sensing of membrane curvature emerges consists the property of lipid membranes without any specific proteins anchored by hydrophobic motif.
:The single liposome binding measurements used biotinylated liposomes of varied sizes, which then labeled with a chromosphore and immobilized by streptavidin. The fluorescence intensity was used to measure the individual liposomal diameters. Another chromophore was used to tag the molecule of interest, and the ratio of the two fluorescent signals in order to find the density of labeled molecules to each individual liposome.
:The binding of amphipathic alpha-helical peptides to the immobilized liposomes were discovered to plot against the amphipathic alpha-helical diameter. The density of peptide stayed constant for measurements of 200nm and above; the measurement increases sharply below 50nm. The equilibrium constant Kd was discovered with little contribution to curvature-selective binding at concentration below Kd.
==Prove== :A geometrical model in highly-curved membranes with a greater density of lipid packing defects provide sites for amphiphilic molecules to insert themselves. The density of binding increases the area of outer leaflet of a membrane. At higher concentration, the interactions are saturated and the defect density effect will predominate. After all, the peptide density will become proportional to defect density, the results for prptides will then fit with the model.
:The model can determine the insertion of any amphiphilic molecules with curvature selective. Scientist uses simple alkyl chains with palmitoyl motif to test the property of model. All alkyl chains are sensors of membrane curvature comparable to amphipathic alpha-helical peptides. The head group of alkyl chains without any influence alter to chain itself. Also, the proteins can be added to the chains without affect the curvature-sensing properties.
==Conclusion== :Overall, the membrane curvature is a generic mechanism to influence the localization of all amphiphilic molecules. Under the effect of concentration of fusogenic lipids in the membrane, membrane curvature can play an important role for protein trafficking and cell signaling in the study of science.
==Reference== :Hatzakis, N. S., Bhatia, V. K., Larsen, J., Madsen, K. L., Bolinger, P-Y., Kunding, A. H., Castillo, J., Gether, U., Hedegård, P. & Stamou, D. How curved membranes recruit amphipathic helices and protein anchoring motifs. Nature Chemical Biology (13 September 2009). doi:10.1038/nchembio.213 {{BookCat}}

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Rkndlwl!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks. --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 10:07, 28 November 2011 (UTC)

page.title: Sport Innovation/Goal-line Technology/Nine Technology Systems being tested by FIFA

revision.text:
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIFA FIFA] has announced that nine goal-line technology systems will undergo vigorous testing in a bid to be approved for match-day use in the 2012-13 EPL season [2]. However, they will not disclose the full list of the nine candidates being assessed by the independent company Swiss Federal Laboratories for Materials Science and Technology ( or [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empa Empa] - German acronym for "Eidgenössische Materialprüfungs- und Forschungsanstalt") attached to the Zurich University [2].
Although the complete list has not been disclosed, two of the technologies are known to be included on the list are the Adidas-backed firm [[Sport Innovation/Goal-line Technology/Cairos GLT System|Cairos]] and [[Sport Innovation/Goal-line Technology/Goalminder|Goalminder]], the brainchild of Bolton Wanderers fans Harry Barnes and David Parden [3].
Each of the nine technologies will be tested in order to determine whether or not they meet the [[Sport Innovation/Goal-line Technology/FIFA Testing Criteria for Goal-line technologies|strict testing criteria]] laid out by FIFA. Should the technologies meet the criteria they will be invited to phase two of the trials [3].
'''REFERENCES'''
<small>[1] Conway, R. (2011, November 24). Premier League could use goal-line technology in 2012-13 season. Retrieved November 29, 2011, from http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/15866363.stm
[2] Nine systems to be tested in goal-line technology trials. (n.d.). Retrieved November 28, 2011, from http://www.soccerex.com/industry-news/nine-systems-to-be-tested-in-goal-line-technology-trials/
[3] Jackson, J. (2011, 24 November). Goal-line technology to be in place for 2012-13 Premier League season. The Guardian. Retrieved November 28, 2011, from http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/nov/24/goalline-technology-fifa-ifab-rochdale?INTCMP=SRCH</small> {{BookCat}}

page.title: Sport Innovation/Goal-line Technology/Arguments for the introduction of goal-line technology

revision.text:
Although there are some standalone arguments as to why goal-line technology should be implemented the majority are rebuttals to the arguments put forward [[Sport Innovation/Goal-line Technology/Arguments against the introduction of goal-line technology|against]] the introduction of [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goal-line_technology goal-line technology]. Below details the reasons GLT should be implemented:
The [[Sport Innovation/Goal-line Technology/FIFA Testing Criteria for Goal-line technologies|criteria]] developed by FIFA to test [[Sport Innovation/Goal-line Technology/Nine Technology Systems being tested by FIFA|nine different systems]] clearly states that they must achieve a 100% accuracy in order to progress from phase to phase during the testing. Thus, inaccuracy of the technology should not be considered as a negative aspect of the technology implemented [1].
The thought that play will be stopped for extended periods of time or that the flow of the game will be disrupted because of the technology is incorrect. Again, the criterion used by FIFA to determine which technology to use has a strict rule concerning this. The criteria states that referees must receive an indication of whether a goal has been scored immediatly and automatically confirmed within one second via the vibration and visual signal to the referees watch [1].
Supporters of technology in football say goal-line incidents are the only decisions that are entirely definitive and the answer can be provided to the referee within one second of the incident occurring [2]. The ball either crossed the line or it didn’t. The technology would not replace referees, it would help them [3] [4].
With the every increasing statistics regarding sports betting, there is simply just too much money involved in the sport to have incorrect decision made. An incorrect decision could also affect the outcome of the game being played. A disallowed goal could be the confidence breaker that allows a team to be beaten. A allowed non-goal could mean a losing team getting an advantage over the other.
Although there are cases both for and [[Sport Innovation/Goal-line Technology/Arguments against the introduction of goal-line technology|against]] the implementation of the technology, the stronger of the two and the [[Sport Innovation/Goal-line Technology/Football, Technology and the future|future]] of sport seems to moving it towards the implementation of technology.
'''REFERENCES'''
<small>[1] Conway, R. (2011, November 24). Premier League could use goal-line technology in 2012-13 season. Retrieved November 29, 2011, from http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/15866363.stm
[2] Gibson, O. (2010, June 28). World Cup 2010: Stubborn FIFA rules out using Goal-line technology. The Guardian. Retrieved November 29, 2011, from http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2010/jun/28/world-cup-2010-goal-line-technology-fifa
[3] Jackson, J. (2011, 24 November). Goal-line technology to be in place for 2012-13 Premier League season. The Guardian. Retrieved November 28, 2011, from http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/nov/24/goalline-technology-fifa-ifab-rochdale?INTCMP=SRCH
[4] Michel Platini warns against introduction of goal-line technology. (2010, October 25). Retrieved November 28, 2011, from http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2010/oct/25/michel-platini-goalline-technology-uefa?INTCMP=SRCH</small> {{BookCat}}

page.title: Sport Innovation/Goal-line Technology/Arguments against the introduction of goal-line technology

revision.text:
Over the past decade the debate as to whether or not goal-line technology should be introduced into Football has produced many compelling arguments both for and against its introduction. The majority of arguments against the introduction have stemmed from [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fifa FIFA] presidents [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sepp_Blatter Sepp Blatter]. A summary of those arguments include: :• The potential inaccuracy of the technology :• The difficulty in controlling the new ball :• The game will no longer be the same at all levels :• The high cost of implementing the technology :• It undermines the concept that the referees decision is final :• The human element of decision making in other areas of the game is still substantial and does not reduce the risk of inaccuracy :• Finally that spectators love the debate
What appears to be the primary concerns of FIFA president, Sepp Blatter, is the potential the inaccuracy of the technology, whether it can detect if the whole of the ball has crossed the line and the delay in transmitting data. There have also been complaints from players, [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clarence_Seedorf Clarence Seedorf] and [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hugo_Ibarra Hugo Ibarra], who have tested the technology regarding the difficulty in controlling the new ball and its trajectory [1].
Also on the list of arguments against the introduction of GLT is ‘universality’ [2]. Those opposed to the introduction claim that it would separate the games played in the park from that played in the stadiums. Sepp Blatterr has been quoted on several occasions saying that the game must be played in the same way no matter where in the world [3]. Whether it’s a team of under 12s playing in a small town, they will be playing with the same rules as the professional players as seen on television.
Not all teams will be able to afford the rumoured half a million pounds to install and implement the technology. The oldest association football competition in the world, the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FA_Cup FA Cup], allows teams from the largest clubs in England and Wales down to amateur village teams to play. Clearly not all teams within the Cup will be able to afford the technology.
There are fears that the introduction of the technology could undermine the concept that the referee's decision is final [2]. Some skeptics believe that players will take advantage of the technology and begin to challenge all other calls made by the referees.
Sepp Blatter has continued to argue that football must retain its human aspect. He believe that not matter which technology is applied, at the end of the day a decision will have to be made by a human being [4]. So why remove the responsibility from the referee and give it to someone else [5]. It is not just decisions regarding goal that could affect the outcome of a game. Referees also make decisions regarding offside players and those who foul. In recent years there have been games in which case a player has been offside or fouled and the team has gone on to score [6].
A final argument endorsed by FIFA's president against the introduction of GLT is that the fans love the debate [5]. He believes long after the game will the fans continue to discuss the issue. So, as long as fans are talking about football, whether it be in a positive or negative way, it is good for the sport.
'''REFERENCES'''
<small>[1] Rudd, S. (2010, March 8). Is Sepp Blatter for Real? Retrieved November 30, 2011, from http://www.footballfancast.com/2010/03/football-blogs/sepp-blatter-real
[2] Gibson, O. (2010, June 28). World Cup 2010: Stubborn FIFA rules out using Goal-line technology. The Guardian. Retrieved November 29, 2011, from http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2010/jun/28/world-cup-2010-goal-line-technology-fifa
[3] Football’s rejection of Goal-line tech. (2010, June 24). Retrieved November 28, 2011, from http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/click_online/8757936.stm
[4] Kelso, P. (2010, June 27). England v Germany: Frank Lampard’s ‘goal’ reignites goal-line technology debate. The Telegraph. Retrieved November 20, 2011, from http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/7857951/England-v-Germany-Frank-Lampards-goal-reignites-goal-line-technology-debate.html
[5] Gibson, O. (2010, June 27). World Cup 2010: Sports Minister joins calls for Goal-line Technology. The Guardian. Retrieved from http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2010/jun/27/world-cup-2010-goal-line-technology?INTCMP=SRCH
[6] O’Hara, A. (2011, November 28). Technology debate must press pause. Retrieved November 30, 2011, from http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/premier-league/technology-debate-must-press-pause-2947179.html</small> {{BookCat}}

page.title: Sport Innovation/Goal-line Technology/FIFA Testing Criteria for Goal-line technologies

revision.text:
[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIFA FIFA] have released the criteria they have developed in order to determine each of the nine technologies accuracy, reliability and instantaneousness [1]. The nine technologies will be evaluated using a pass or fail assessment system with 100% accuracy required. The four criteria include:
# The technology applies solely to the goal-line and only to determine whether a goal has been scored # The system must be accurate # The indication of whether a goal has been scored must be immediate and automatically confirmed within one second # The indication of whether a goal has been scored will only be communicated to the match officials (via the referee's watch, by vibration and visual signal) [2]
During phase one all of the technologies will be tested with varying levels of lighting, speed of the ball, different angles of trajectory[3]. Not only with the technology be tested with regards to the ball going through the goal posts but the ball will also be tested to determine if players will have the same control of the ball embedded with the technology as one without [1].
Phase two of the testing will be more intensive and will take in various elements such as climatic conditions and receptiveness of referees' watches, which would receive the verdicts from the technology [1].
The findings from the testing will be presented by [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empa Empa] to the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Football_Association_Board International Football Association Board] (IFAB). Those who meet the criteria will be voted on by the board which is comprised of the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Football_Association Football Association] (FA), the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_FA Irish FA], the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welsh_FA Welsh FA], the [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scottish_fa Scottish FA] and FIFA. Each of the FA’s have one vote while FIFA who will act on behalf of the rest of the world, has four votes. The decision to implement one of the GLTs must be approved by three-quarters of the IFAB member [4].
'''REFERENCES'''
<small>[[1] Conway, R. (2011, November 24). Premier League could use goal-line technology in 2012-13 season. Retrieved November 29, 2011, from http://news.bbc.co.uk/ sport2/hi/football/15866363.stm
[2] Nine systems to be tested in goal-line technology trials. (n.d.). Retrieved November 28, 2011, from http://www.soccerex.com/industry-news/nine-systems-to-be-tested-in-goal-line-technology-trials/
[3] FIFA to run tests on nine goal-line technology systems this autumn. (2011, 21 July). Retrieved November 29, 2011, from http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/jul/21/fifa-goal-line-technology?INTCMP=SRCH
[4] Jackson, J. (2011, 24 November). Goal-line technology to be in place for 2012-13 Premier League season. The Guardian. Retrieved November 28, 2011, from http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/nov/24/goalline-technology-fifa-ifab-rochdale?INTCMP=SRCH </small> {{BookCat}}

The Cairos GLT system, which is backed by sports giant [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adidas Adidas], utilises an electronic system which has sensors imbedded inside the match ball as well as electromagnetic strips buried under the goal [1]. The whole process takes less that one second. The way the system works is a four step process: # Thin cables are installed in the turf of the penalty area and behind the goal line. Each cable has a unique amount of electricity running through it that generates a magnetic field # A sensor is implanted in the ball which measures the magnetic field as soon as it crosses the line. The sensor then sends encrypted data to receivers located behind the goal. # The receivers then send encrypted data to a computer in order to be processed. # Once the computer has determine the entire ball has crossed the line an encrypted signal is sent to the referees watch [2]
The implantation of a chip suspended inside the ball has no impact on the handling characteristics. Players will not notice the difference between a ball with an implanted chip or a ball without the chip [3].
One of the main concerns of those who against the introduction of the technology is that of cost. Cairos Direct or Marketing and Communications has explained that Cairos will absorb the cost for the installation of the technology and will only change a small portion of what it would cost to pay four referees per game. In return for the free installation the technology provider would seek the rights to sell sponsorship of the system at each ground [4].
The system which was originally tested in 2005 at the U-17 FIFA World Cup has since been refined and retested at the 2007 FIFA Club World Cup in Japan and had an accuracy rating of 100% [5]. Currently the Cairos GLT System meets all [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IFAB International Football Association Board (IFAB)] [[Sport Innovation/Goal-line Technology/FIFA Testing Criteria for Goal-line technologies|criteria]] and the ball has been approved by [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIFA FIFA] for competitive international play [5].
'''REFERENCES'''
<small><small>[1] Conway, R. (2011, November 24). Premier League could use goal-line technology in 2012-13 season. Retrieved November 29, 2011, from http://news.bbc.co.uk/ sport2/hi/football/15866363.stm
[2] Goal-line Technology (GLT) System. (n.d.) Retrieved November 29, 2011, from http://www.cairos.com/unternehmen/gltsystem.php?sl=1
[3] Emery, D. (2010, June 28). Goal-line technology firms dispute Fifa. Retrieved November 29, 2011, from http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10435958
[4] Goal-line Technology – Getting it right. (2010). Retrieved November 29, 2011, from http://www.wipo.int/wipo_magazine/en/2010/04/article_0001.html
[5] McKeegan, N. (2007, December 13). The Adidas intelligent football. Retrieved November 29, 2011, from http://www.gizmag.com/adidas-intelligent-football/8512/ </small></small> {{BookCat}}

Goalminder technology came about when [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolton_Wanderers_F.C. Bolton Wanderers] fans, Harry Barnes and David Parden, were outraged when a [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerry_Taggart Gerry Taggart's] goal was disallowed in 1997 and the club went on to be relegated [1]. Fourteen years later their technology, which retails for approximately £100,000 for a set of two goal posts, uses 24 high speed cameras built into each of the goal posts and cross bar [2]. The cameras take high quality video at 2,000 frames per second [2]. Inventors, Barnes and Parden say the best factor about their technology is that there is not digging up of the pitch required.
The system works in such a way that when the ball crosses the line, the information collected by the cameras is verified by a computer which uses three-dimensional imaging software. Only if the ball has completely crossed the line and a goal has indeed been scored does an encrypted signal get sent to the referee’s watch, which not only sends a visual notice but also triggers a vibration [1]. Goalminder investors say that unlike other technology, Goalminder is real-life footage, meaning it is an accurate way of deciding whether a goal should stand or not [3]. They claim that the embedded cameras can detect within one second if a ball has crossed the goal line. Therefore there is no delay to the game [1].
Earlier in 2011 the system was analysed by FIFA’s testers, independent company Swiss Federal Laboratories for Materials Science and Technology ( or Empa - German acronym for "Eidgenössische Materialprüfungs- und Forschungsanstalt"), at Rochdale’s spotland ground [4]. The Rochdale tests are part of the first phase of the trials of [[Sport Innovation/Goal-line Technology/Nine Technology Systems being tested by FIFA|nine goal-line technologies]] assessing if they meet the [[Sport Innovation/Goal-line Technology/FIFA Testing Criteria for Goal-line technologies|strict testing criteria]] developed by [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IFAB IFAB] [5]. Since the tests it has become known that Goalminder has now been invited to take part in the second phase of testing to be carried out within the next 12 months [2].
FIFA officials are concerned about the cost of the technology and who will have to pay for its purchase and installation. The cost to purchase and installation the Goalminder technology could be offset by potential sponsorship and advertising that is attractive in terms of value added as well as the potential commercial value [2].
'''REFERENCES'''
<small>[1] Conway, R. (2011, November 24). Premier League could use goal-line technology in 2012-13 season. Retrieved November 29, 2011, from http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/15866363.stm
[2] Goalminder Technology. (n.d.). Retrieved November 29, 2011, from http://www.goalminder.co.uk/goal-line-technology.html
[3] Goalminder aims to end goal-line errors. (2011, October 11). Retrieved November 29, 2011, from http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/business/enterprise/s/1461303_goalminder-aims-to-end-goal-line-errors
[4] Jackson, J. (2011, 24 November). Goal-line technology to be in place for 2012-13 Premier League season. The Guardian. Retrieved November 28, 2011, from http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2011/nov/24/goalline-technology-fifa-ifab-rochdale?INTCMP=SRCH
[5] Dovaston, I. (2011, November 24). FIFA at Rochdale FC to test Goal-line cameras. Retrieved November 30, 2011, from http://news.sky.com/home/uk-news/article/16116528</small> {{BookCat}}

snmbala is a short tag keyword hinting for Balamurugan. He is basically from Tamil Nadu. He born in Manamadurai (a town 40Km away from Madurai) in Jan 3 1986. He did his schools at his hometown till 8th grade. He is not so good at studies. Normally look less confident in what ever he do. His father use to encourage him in many ways. in 1999, his father joined him a school at Madurai, concerning his studies. Next four years he stayed in hostel. Those four year become his unforgettable days life long for him. Once he completed his schools he join in Thiagarajar college, Madurai. He completed his bachelors in Industrial Microbiology there. His studies went smooth over there. Once after that he went bangalore for his higher studies. That's the greatest time in his life. He learn a lot, Earn a lot and off-course struggled a lot. He had a mixed life in bangalore. He join in Oxford science college for his masters in Biotechnology. His class is full of north indian's who are all from different culture. He was initially conservative and less spoken. Later he realize the hidden skill with in him, he worked on it constantly, and got everybody's attention. Near to the end of his studies he was fighting with his ego, fear and loneliness. he was very much worried about his job, and quit lonely for sometime. later he got a chance from a government organisation, under which he will get free training from a company as well as stipend for it. For the next 6 months he stayed in company hostel and did his training. He has no clue how the training will help him. Training got end. He had some good time's over there. But he is not full happy. He has not completely come out of his lonely feeling. Once the training is over he searched for job. He got few interview call. he felt very difficult to clear a interview. He has not got any job. At that time his mother had operation in stomach. He rushed to see his mother. He stayed and helped his mother for a month. Then later he went again to bangalore and stayed with his friends room. He realize biotech has very less job. and his current potency is not competitive with others. He started thinking why can't he move his career in something which he is interested. He figured out his interest in graphic design and explaining things. Since he's from biotech background he thought why can't he move his career on his interest in parallel with career. He search for companies, who work on life science field, related to his interest. He figured out few companies. In addition to that he attend interview on other IT companies also. he is not able to clear any interview. Atlast he thought there is something wrong with this personality and approach. So he thought he can join in a personality training institute. He joined a course for a month and also went for a web development course in the morning. Web development course was a whole waste of time for him.

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=413]]
==Annotations== '''''Vidi aquam egredientem de templo a latere dextro. Alleluia'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''I saw water coming out of the temple on the right-hand side''.Gifford (1988) 453.
Thornton (1968) 359. This is not from the ''[[w:Introit|Introit]]'' for [[w:Paschal Tide|paschal time]]; it is the opening phrase of one of the [[w:Antiphon|antiphons]] that may be sung during [[w:Eastertide|Eastertide]] in the [[w:Asperges|Asperges]], or rite of sprinkling the congregation with holy water, a penitential rite that ordinarily precedes the principal Mass on Sunday. This particular antiphon is based on [[w:Book of Ezekiel|Ezekiel 47]][http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Ezekiel%2047&version=VULGATE Ezekiel 47.] and [[w:Psalms|Psalms 117]] (Vulgate):[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Psalmi+117&version=VULGATE Psalms 117.] {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Vidi Aquam'''''[http://www.archive.org/stream/MissaleRomanum1603#page/n883/mode/1up ''Missale Romanum (1603)'' 883.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Vidi aquam egredientem de templo,'' ''A latere dextro, Alleluia:'' ''Et omnes, ad quos pervenit aqua ista,'' ''Salvi facti sunt, et dicent, Alleluia, Alleluia.'' '''V.''' ''Confitemini Domino quoniam bonus:'' '''R.''' ''Quoniam in saeculum misericordia eius.'' '''V.''' ''Gloria Patri, et Filio, et Spiritui Sancto:'' '''R.''' ''Sicut erat in principio, et nunc, et semper,'' ''Et in saecula sæculorum. Amen.'' | ''I saw water coming forth from the temple'' ''On the right side, Alleluia:'' ''And all those to whom this water came'' ''Were saved, and shall say, Alleluia, Alleluia.'' '''V.''' ''Give praise to the Lord, for He is good:'' '''R.''' ''For His mercy endureth forever.'' '''V.''' ''Glory be to the Father, and to the Son, and to the Holy Spirit:'' '''R.''' ''As it was in the beginning, is now, and ever shall be,'' ''World without end. Amen.'' |} '''''Altius aliquantulum'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Somewhat higher''.Gifford (1988) 453. Gifford translates this incorrectly as "with considerable profundity"; it is actually a reference to the fact that this verse is sung at a slightly higher pitch than the first verse in the traditional chant.[http://musicasacra.com/pdf/liberusualis.pdf ''Liber Usualis'' 12.] (PDF page 124.) '''''Et omnes ad quos pervenit aqua istas'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''And all those to whom this water came.'' See '''410.22''' above.Gifford (1988) 453. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/409|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/411|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=414]]
==Annotations== '''''Triumphaliter'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Triumphantly''.Gifford (1988) 453. The traditional chant for ''Vidi Aquam'' reaches it highest note on the first syllable of ''facti''.[http://musicasacra.com/pdf/liberusualis.pdf ''Liber Usualis'' 12.] (PDF page 124.) I have not actually found the adverb ''triumphaliter'' in any Latin dictionary, but the adjective ''[[wikt:triumphalis|triumphalis]]'' (''triumphant'') does exist, and the standard method of turning such an adjective into an adverb would give ''triumphaliter''. See, for example, ''trivialiter''.[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.04.0059:entry=trivialiter ''A Latin Dictionary''.] '''''Salvi facti i sunt'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Erratum'') This should read: ''Salvi facti sunt''.{{cite book |title=Ulysses: The Corrected Text |last=Joyce |first=James |editor=Hans Walter Gabler |others=With Wolfhard Steppe and Claus Melchior |year=1986 |publisher=The Bodley Head |location=London |page=353}} Gabler also emends ''Triumphaliter'' by removing the italics and putting the ''T'' in lower case. {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ |- style="vertical-align: top;" | '''Erratum''' (''Triumphaliter.'') ''Salvi facti i sunt.'' | '''Recte''' (''Triumphaliter.'') ''Salvi facti sunt.'' |} '''''Salvi facti sunt'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Were saved.''Gifford (1988) 453. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Circe/410|410.22]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/410|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/412|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=415]]
==Annotations== '''''ad deam qui laetificat juventutem meam'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''to the goddess who gladdens my youth''.Gifford (1988) 454.
Thornton (1968) 360. Stephen has adapted a phrase from the [[w:Tridentine Mass|Latin Tridentine Mass]], which was still in use in 1904. At the start of the Mass, during the ''Prayers at the Foot of the Altar'', the Priest intones the words: ''Introibo ad altare Dei'' (''I will go into the altar of God''). To this the servers respond: ''Ad Deum qui laetificat iuventutem meam'' (''To God who gladdens my youth''). See also [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Telemachus/003|003.05]]. Joyce's spelling ''[[wikt:juventus|juventutem]]'' is an acceptable alternative to ''[[wikt:iuventus|iuventutem]]''. Gabler emends the text in favour of the latter.{{cite book |title=Ulysses: The Corrected Text |last=Joyce |first=James |editor=Hans Walter Gabler |others=With Wolfhard Steppe and Claus Melchior |year=1986 |publisher=The Bodley Head |location=London |page=353}} ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/411|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/413|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
Reference for this section: "Fractions without Quotients: Arithmetic of Repeating Decimals" by Richard Plagge. The College Mathematics Journal, Vol. 10, No. 1, (1978), pp. 11-15.
In the paper above the author shows how you can define addition and multiplication directly on repeating decimals. One reasons this is interesting is that it makes, using these operations one can make sense out of proofs that 0.999... = 1 ''without'' the real numbers, convergence, etc. I bumped into this when I was thinking about stuff like [[User:Thenub314/Musings]]. I had written down the algorithms myself, and then when I thought about writing them up I found it had already been done. [[User:Thenub314|Thenub]][[Special:Contributions/Thenub314|314]] ([[User talk:Thenub314|talk]]) 13:19, 28 November 2011 (UTC)

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=451]]
==Annotations== '''Namine. Jacobs Vobiscum. Amen'''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') A corrupted conflation of two Latin liturgical phrases:''in nomine Domini'' (''in the name of the Lord'') and ''Dominus vobiscum'' (''the Lord be with you''), together with an allusion to the Dublin [[wikt:biscuit|biscuit]] manufacturer William & R. Jacob & Co. Ltd.Gifford (1988) 469.
Thornton (1968) 371. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Hades/100|100.01]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Sirens/246|246.16]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Sirens/272|272.17-20]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Sirens/277|277.37]], [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Cyclops/293|293.07]] and [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Cyclops/326|326.02]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/447|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/449|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=455]]
==Annotations== '''''Cui bona?'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Who benefits by it?''.Gifford (1988) 470.
Thornton (1968) 373-374. The adage ''[[w:Cui bona|cui bona]]'' is often used colloquialy to mean ''of what use is it?''. '''''aurora borealis'''''{{spaces|5}}The [[w:Aurora_(astronomy)|Northern Lights]]. See [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Circe/413|413.24]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=459]]
==Annotations== '''''Gaudium magnum annuntio vobis. Habemus carnificem'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''A great joy I announce to you. We have an executioner.'' This is a corruption of the opening lines of the traditional formula known as ''[[w:Habemus Papam|Habemus Papam]]'' which is uttered by the [[w:Protodeacon|Senior Cardinal Deacon]] to announce the election of a new Pope: ''Annuntio vobis gaudium magnum: Habemus Papam!'' (''I announce to you a great joy: We have a Pope!'').Gifford (1988) 474.
Thornton (1968) 376. Gifford cites ''Habemus pontificem'' (''We have a Pontiff'') as the correct form, which is closer to Joyce's ''Habemus carnificem''. This form is supported by a contemporary account of the election of Pope Pius X in 1903.{{cite book |title=A Pilgrimage to See the Holy Father, Pope Pius X |year=1904 |publisher=Underwood & Underwood |location=New York and London |pages=31-32| url=http://www.archive.org/stream/apilgrimagetosee00unknuoft#page/30/mode/2up}} '''Copula Felix'''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Fertile Coupling''.Gifford (1988) 474.
Thornton (1968) 376. Thornton sees this as an allusion to ''[[w:Felix culpa|felix culpa]]'' (''happy fall'') in the ''[[w:Exsultet|Exultet]]'', from which Stephen quoted earlier in the day; see [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Proteus/050|050.04-05]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/455|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/457|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=460]]
==Annotations== '''''Bonafide Sabaoth'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'', ''Hebrew'') ''Genuine Hosts''.Gifford (1988) 475.
Thornton (1968) 377. If ''Bonafide'' is taken to be a corruption of the Latin ''bona fide'' (''in good faith''), the warcry could mean ''Hosts of the True Faith''; the Turks at Plevna were Muslims. '''Nova Hibernia'''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''New Ireland''.Gifford (1988) 475. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/456|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/458|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=464]]
==Annotations== '''''Acid. nit. hydrochlor dil'', 20 minims'''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Acidum nitro-hydrocloricum dilutum'' (''Dilute nitro-hydrocloric acid'', 20 drops).Gifford (1988) 478. A [[wikt:minim|minim]] is a unit of liquid measure approximately equivalent to the volume of a drop of water. Nitro-hydrochloric acid is also known as ''[[w:Aqua regia|aqua regia]]''. '''''Tinct. mix. vom'', 5 minims'''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Tinctura nucis vomicae'' (''Tincture of nux vomica'', 5 drops).Gifford (1988) 478. Gabler emends Joyce's ''mix. vom'' to ''nux vom.,'' which makes sense. Tincture of nux vomica is a stimulant prepared from the [[w:Strychnos nux-vomica|Strychnine tree]]. '''''Extr. taraxel. lig.'' 30 minims.'''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Extractum taraxaci liquidum'' (''Liquid extract of dandelion'', 30 drops).Gifford (1988) 478. Gabler emends Joyce's ''lig.'' to ''liq.'' The Latin for ''dandelion'' is ''taraxacum'', so it is possible that Joyce's ''taraxel.'' has been corrupted. This liquid extract is prepared from the dried dandelion root; it is prescribed as a [[wikt:stomachic|stomachic]] and liver stimulant, often with diluted nitro-hydrochloric acid and tincture of nux vomica.[http://www.henriettesherbal.com/eclectic/bpc1911/taraxacum.html Taraxaci Radix.] '''''Aq. dis. ter in die.'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Aqua distillata ter in die'' (''Distilled water three times a day'').Gifford (1988) 478. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/460|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/462|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=468]]
==Annotations== '''''virgo intacta'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''undefiled virgin''.Gifford (1988) 481. This is the medical term for a girl or woman whose [[wikt:hymen|hymen]] is unbroken, which generally indicates that she has never had [[wikt:sexual intercourse|sexual intercourse]]. '''''fetor judaicus'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Jewish stench''.Gifford (1988) 481. It is said that the myth that Jews emit a fetid stink derives from an error (possibly deliberate) of a medieval copyist, who mistranscribed a passage by [[w:Ammianus Marcellinus|Ammianus Marcellinus]], replacing ''Judaeorum petentium'' (''of the attacking Jews'') with ''Judaeorum fetentium'' (''of the ill-smelling Jews'').[http://www.thelatinlibrary.com/ammianus/22.shtml Ammianus Marcellinus 22:5:5.] and [http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/ammianus_22_book22.htm#C5 English.]
{{cite book |title=The Jews: A Study of Race and Environment |last=Fishberg |first=Maurice |year=1911 |publisher=The Walter Scott Publishing Company |location=London |page=314 |url=http://www.archive.org/stream/jewsastudyracea00fishgoog#page/n335/mode/1up}} Joyce is believed to have read this book; see Ellmann (1982) 395 and note. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/464|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/466|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.comment:

==Annotations== ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="ba..."

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=470]]
==Annotations== '''''Leopoldi autem generatio'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Now, the begetting of Leopold''.Gifford (1988) 482.
Thornton (1968) 384. The words parody the opening of Matthew 1:18: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Matthew 1:18'''''[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew%201:18&version=VULGATE Matthew 1:18.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Christi autem generatio sic erat: cum esset desponsata mater eius Maria Ioseph, antequam convenirent, inventa est in utero habens de Spiritu Sancto.'' | ''Now the birth of Jesus Christ was on this wise: When as his mother Mary was espoused to Joseph, before they came together, she was found with child of the Holy Ghost.'' |} But the genealogy of Christ is given in Matthew 1:1, which would make more sense here: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Matthew 1:1'''''[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew%201:1&version=VULGATE Matthew 1:1.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Liber generationis Iesu Christi filii David filii Abraham.'' | ''The book of the generation of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham.'' |} '''''et vocabitur nomen eius Emmanuel'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''and his name shall be called Emmanuel''.Gifford (1988) 483.
Thornton (1968) 384. The words allude to Isaiah 7:14: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Isaiah 7:14'''''[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Isaiah%207:14&version=VULGATE Isaiah 7:14.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Propter hoc dabit Dominus ipse vobis signum; ecce, virgo concipiet, et pariet filium, et vocabitis nomen eius Emmanuhel.'' | ''Therefore the Lord himself shall give you a sign; Behold, a virgin shall conceive, and bear a son, and you shall call his name Immanuel.'' |} This verse is cited in Matthew 1:23: {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Matthew 1:23'''''[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew%201:23&version=VULGATE Matthew 1:23.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Ecce, virgo in utero habebit, et pariet filium, et vocabunt nomen eius Emmanuhel, quod est interpretatum, Nobiscum Deus.'' | ''Behold, a virgin shall be with child, and shall bring forth a son, and they shall call his name Emmanuel, which being interpreted is, God with us.'' |} Joyce's form also recalls Isaiah 9:6, which is quoted in the ''Hallelujah Chorus'' of [[w:George Frideric Handel|Handel's]] ''[[w:Messiah (Handel)|Messiah]]'' (alluded to below at [[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Circe/470|470.21]]): {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Isaiah 9:6'''''[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Isaias+9:6&version=KJV Isaiah 9:6.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Parvulus enim natus est nobis, filius datus est nobis: et factus est principatus super umerum eius: et vocabitur nomen eius Admirabilis, Consiliarius, Deus fortis, Pater futuri saeculi, Princeps pacis.'' | ''For unto us a child is born, unto us a son is given: and the government shall be upon his shoulder: and his name shall be called Wonderful, Counsellor, The mighty God, The everlasting Father, The Prince of Peace.'' |} ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/466|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/468|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=477]]
==Annotations== '''''Cœla enarrant gloriam Domini'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''The heavens expound the glory of the Lord''.Gifford (1988) 487.
Thornton (1968) 388. Stephen has misquoted the opening words of Psalms 19 (Vulgate 18:2): {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Psalms 18:2a'''''[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Psalms%2018:1-2&version=VULGATE Psalms 18:1-2.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Caeli enarrant gloriam Dei;'' | ''The heavens declare the glory of God;'' |} ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/473|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/475|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=486]]
==Annotations== '''Contact with a goldring, they say'''{{spaces|5}}It is still a common superstition that contact with a gold ring will cure a stye.Gifford (1988) 494. This, apparently, is based on the myth that styes (and acne) occur in young women at the onset of menstruation due to sexual repression or masturbation. The cure is marriage (i.e. contact with a gold ''wedding'' ring).{{cite journal |last1=Inman |first1=W. S. |year=1946 |title=Styes, Barley and Wedding Rings |journal=The British Journal of Medical Psychology |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |volume=20 |issue=4 |pages=331-338}} '''''Argumentum ad feminam'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''Argument to the woman''.Gifford (1988) 494.
Thornton (1968) 396. ''[[wikt:argumentum ad hominem|Argumentum ad hominem]]'' (''argument to the person'') is the name of a [[w:Ad hominem|fallacious form of reasoning]] in which one attempts to refute a statement by discrediting the person who asserts that statement. ''Argumentum ad feminam'' generally denotes a fallacy in which the lynchpin of the argument reflects poorly on female nature. Virag seems to be alluding to the myth (see the previous annotation) that styes in young women are caused by sexual repression or masturbation, the cure being marriage to a man. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/482|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/484|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}

revision.text:
[[File:Ulysses, 1922.djvu|thumb|600px|center|page=533]]
==Annotations== '''''Et exaltabuntur cornua iusti'''''{{spaces|5}}(''Latin'') ''And the horns of the just man shall be exalted''.Gifford (1988) 513.
Thornton (1968) 413. This is adapted from Psalms 75:10 (Vulgate 74:11): {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="center" |+ '''''Psalms 75:10'''''[http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Psalms%2074&version=VULGATE Psalms 75.] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | ''Et omnia cornua impiorum confringam; exaltabuntur cornua iusti.'' | ''All the horns of the wicked also will I cut off; but the horns of the righteous shall be exalted.'' |} Stephen is adding a sexual dimension that is not present in the original, echoing Lenehan's ''Got the horn or what?'' to Boylan in ''[[Annotations_to_James_Joyce's_Ulysses/Sirens/256|Sirens]]''. ==References== {{reflist}} {|style="width: 23%; margin: 0px auto;" class="noprint" |style="background-color: #efe; border: 1px solid SteelBlue; padding: 0.5em; font-size: small; text-align: center;"|'''[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses]]'''
[[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/529|Preceding Page]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Page Index|Page Index]] | [[Annotations to James Joyce's Ulysses/Circe/531|Next Page]] |} {{BookCat}}
